4922170/4858123/5130428.title: A Story of Daniel O'Connell
4922170/4858123/5130428.text: A Story of Daniel O'ConnellOnce when Daniel O'Connell was in London he met with a boor boy who charged with committing a theft and he asked O'Connell to help him. O'Connell at once handed him fourpence and said to him."Try and get a pair of boots for fourpence but don't go to court without them and when you have reached the court I will follow you."The poor boy obeyed with a glad heart and he was very lucky in procuring a pair of boots with the money. He was under his trial at the court when O'Connell arrived and the Judge on seeing O'Connell said to him."Have you known this man for long?""I have known him since his boots cost fourpence and there was never anything against him."The Judge thought he must have been very young when he got a pair of boots for fourpence and taking O'Connell at his word he set the boy free.

Long, long ago when the people in Glen Imaal and this part of the county thought Ireland was about to be invaded, they wanted to find out how long it would take to warn the whole of Ireland. So the only thing they could think of was, the first man who received the news, to run off to his neighbour's house and take with him a couple of cáráns and drop them at the door. Then the man of that house would run with the cáráns to his next door neighbour, and so on, until the news was given to the people of every house, through-out the country.

5044660/5029613/5141419.title: (no title)
5044660/5029613/5141419.text: There was a barrack on the mountain not many years ago. The Cantlons, the Abbeys and the hills lived on this mountain. Doyne put them there, he was Mr Kavanagh's agent. He put the people there to take possession of the white mountain. The people of the country and Dan O'Connell put the Cantlon's and the other famlies out. There was an old man named Jones from Ballinlug he was 80 years of age. And Kavanagh and Doynes would give him a large sum of money to stop at home and not to go prove that the white mountain was always free. They got until nine o'clock to clear out. There did many people go to see it being knocked down.

4921577/4881193/5146376.title: A Story about Daniel O' Connell
4921577/4881193/5146376.text:
The following story is about the help Daniel O'Connell gave to a poor woman when she was going to be evicted. The woman was a widow and he was to be evicted for no reason, but that the land should be given to a protestant.The day before the eviction she went to Daniel O'Connell and begged him to plead for her. Daniel O'Connell went to the landlord's agent and asked permission of him to let the woman stay in her possession until to-morrow. He got permission in writing, and gave it to the woman, and when the agent came to-morrow Daniel O'Connell was there before him, and showed him the writing and said she had permission to stay until to-morrow. When the agent came the day after Daniel O'Connell was there before him again, and said that the woman had permission to
(continues on next page)

4921646/4887551/5153015.title: (no title)
4921646/4887551/5153015.text: In the dealyard near the Dispensary was a stage coach (Bianconi) station. Horses were changed  here and fresh horses put to the coach. Mr T. Levis's father travelled from Bandon to school in Dublin by coach.Before Bandon railway was continued west of Bandon carriers with loads of meal and flour were to be seen every morning at Bell's mill.When Daniel O'Connell visited Bandon people from the town went out two  miles on the Dunmanway Road to meet him. They unharnessed the horses from his carriage and drew him into town. He spoke from the balcony of Mrs Healy's Hotel but before doing so had the balcony tested as he feared the Orange men had tampered with it.An old fisherman selling sprats in the town used to shout " Sprit úr 'na mbeathaid agus á dá súil ar oscailt "On Saturday mornings cockles, wrinkles and madhbháns were sold in town. At the back of Gamble's Medical Hall in our yard Mr Stanley made candles and he supplied the town at that time with light. There is one wall standing yet and the stones  are falling off and there is a square hole in the wall. The candles he made were a foot long.

5162177/5161117/5162372.title: O' Connell and the Tinkers
5162177/5161117/5162372.text:
IYou sons of the shamrockGive ear to my dittyI am sure you will say its a comical oneFor to miss such a jokeYou will find it a pityFor our Irish Boys are the fellows for fun.IIThese lines I intend to incline to no party For to favour no sexIn church or in stateIf you only would listenGrant me your directionSome tricks you will laugh atFor me to relate.IIIWhen Daniel O'Connell he first was electedHis very first claim Was a member for ClareThe Cockney's all eagerAnd crowds stood around himWith the cheers of our IrishmenRented the air.Being anxious to seeThis great man of the peopleThe John Bulls in thousands
(continues on next page)

5162177/5161121/5162375.title: O' Connell and the Tinkers
5162177/5161121/5162375.text:
(continued from previous page)
VIIIHis wife she scolded and got in a passion.The tinkers they laughedAs they hammered awayFor they knew very wellHe could not dispossess themAs long as their billThey would continue to payIt was for four daysThey kept up constant hammering The landlord he charged themUpon the first dayTen pounds but was gladTo bestow them one hundredBefore he could get the bold tinkers away.Now since Daniel he first was elected.The rights of old IrelandHe always maintained Lt them never think to play tricks onO'Connell,For they'll never play one On O'Connell again.

4921698/4891072/5162429.title: Dónall Ó Conaill
4921698/4891072/5162429.text: Dómhnall Ó ConaillTá an sgeal so ag na sean daoine i dtaobh Dhomhnaill Uí Chonaill. Do tugadh cuireadh go féasta dho thall i Londain uair ach ní le grádh dho ach a mhallairt. Is amhlaidh a bhí sé beartuighthe aca é chur as a' slíghe mar bhí sé ag deanamh alán díoghbhála dhóibh agus á gcosc ar  sco rudai. Chuireadar nimh sa bhfíon agus chuireadar an gloine fíona san áit go raibh Dómhnall Ó Conaill chun suidhe. Bhí cailín ó Éirinn ag obair sa tigh ceadna agus bhí a fhios aici cad a bhí beartuighthe. Nuair a tháinig Dómhnall Ó Conaill isteach do labhair sí leis as Gaeghilg mar níor theastuig uaithe go dtuigfeadh aoinne eile í. Seo mar adubhairt sí leis:A Dhómhnaill Uí Chonaill an dtuigeann tú Gaedhilg?Cad na thaobh ná tuigfinn, a chailín, is mé bheith ó ÉirinnIth do dhóthain ach ná h-ól braonMar tá salann garbh ar phraisig ó 'rír duit.Imthigh a chailín agus mo bheannacht go léir duitAgus cuirfead-sa an salann san ar duine 'ca féinig.Deirtear ná raibh ach aon chos amháin féin mbórd a bhí ann & gur bórd cómh-chroinn é agus gur bhféidir é casadh ar an gcois sin mar a chasfá roth. Nuair a shuigh Dómhnall chun búird theasbeáin sé figiúirí éigin míorbhúileacha ar an bhfalla le na lámha & trí congnamh an lampa. D'fheucadar go léir ar an bhfalla & le na linn sin thug Dómhnall casadh beag do'n mbórd i dtreó gur ar a aghaidh anonn a bhí an gloine fíona go raibh an nimh ann.

4921786/4906996/5178965.title: Callaghan O' Callaghan and Daniel O' Connell
4921786/4906996/5178965.text: Callaghan O'Callaghan lived in Kerry during Daniel O'Connell's time. He knew English but never spoke a word of anything except Irish. He committed some crime and brought to court. Daneil O'Connell was for the plaintiff of the case. He pretended he did not know English so he had an interpreter. Callaghan O'Callaghan was perjuring himself to a great extent. Daniel O'Connell was cross-examining him as he was a very fat man he was tired from standing so long. Daniel O'Connell then asked him if he knew any English and he shook his head as a sign that he did not. He then told the court that as O'Callaghan was a fat helpless man he must now be tired. He then told O'Callaghan to sit down which he did willingly. Then O'Connell said "There's the man that does not know a word of English and still when I tell him sit down in English he understands me". "I want that man in the dock for perjury".

4921786/4906997/5178966.title: Daniel O' Connell
4921786/4906997/5178966.text:
In the times of Daniel O'Connell there was a man who was called a highwayman by reason of the crimes he had committed.A man in Co. Kerry, to which the prisoner was brought for trial bribed the judge to transport him for life or if he could to hang him.  The bribe he received was a pipe of wine, a measure which contained about ninety gallons.Daniel O'Connell was defending the prisoner.  He knew he had no chance unless he thought of a plan.  He got a fine black horse and gave it to the prisoner's brother.  He knew that the judge was very fond of horses.  The judge was going that way to the trial in Tralee.The prisoner's brother was supposed not to know the judge at all.  When the judge came on he stopped on seeing this fine horse.  He asked the man what price he wanted for the horse.  Before he could answer O'Connell said to the man that it as his lordship the judge was buying.  the owner replied that he would take no money for the horse but would give him as a present to the
(continues on next page)

4921786/4907043/5178992.title: How to Disinfect a House in the Ancient Way
4921786/4907043/5178992.text:
(continued from previous page)
house. Their breath would kill every germ that might be in the house.



Daneil O'Connell was in Dublin and as he was coming out of a train the top of his right ear was cut off. When he came to Cork he asked a shopkeeper how much tobacco it would(?) him to get as would go up to the top of his right ear. The shopkeeper named a price and O'Connell paid. He made the shopkeeper give him as much tobacco as would go from Cork to Dublin because the top of his right ear was in Dublin.

4921786/4907050/5178997.title: The Tinkers Hotel
4921786/4907050/5178997.text: One day Daniel O'Connell met tinkers. There were ladies and gentlemen among them. He told them to go to the city to a hotel and not to leave for a month because tinkers had that power.He then told them that if they did not leave for a month they could obtain L5,000 easily.One night they started hammering and saudering and they continued at this for many days.The proprietor offered a sum of money to them to quit as if they did not the hotel would get a bad name.They would not go however until he gave them L5,000. He agreed to give the sum of money and then they departed. But the hotel never got back its good name. People never stay there now and eversince it has been called the Tinkers Hotel.

4921856/4896615/5189694.title: Stories of Watergrasshill and District from Old Inhabitants - Candles
4921856/4896615/5189694.text:
My father told me he often saw people make candles in moulds when he was a boy, also he saw them make "PÁDÓGS" Rushes from a bog were peeled and the pith allowed to dry for wick. Cotton waste was sometimes used instead of rushes and gave better light. These wicks were then dipped in the pan of grease and laid out to dry, then dipped again till they were of the required thickness.   He often saw the dropping from cattle (manure) dried and used for making fire. It was called "bourrawn"



Daniel O'Connell was once in London, and was invited to dinner to a house, the owner of which was a secret enemy of O'Connell's and had laid plans to poison him.A maid who discovered the plot was the means of saving O'Connell's life. Under cover of waiting at table she gave him the warning   "A Dhónail Uí Chonaill, a dtigeann tú Gaoluinn[?]?""Tuigim go maith, a chailín ó Éirinn.""Tá salann id gloine, agus tá sé ó aréir annIth do dhóthain, ach ná ól aon rud."

5190451/4895155/5190529.title: A Funny Story
5190451/4895155/5190529.text: A Funny StoryLong long ago a stranger came to Dublin for a holiday and he asked Daniel O'Connell to show him the principal buildings in Dublin. So one morning Daniel and himself set off to see the buildings. When they came to Nelso's Pillar Daniel said this is one of Dublin's principal buildings. O my! O my! said the stranger, "you would get a bottle of stout in England twice bigger than that. Then they came to another fine building O my! O my! said the stranger "you would get a sandwich in England twice bigger than that". Daniel was getting very sick of the stranger, when a huge train came up the city carrying on top of it a half mile of rail for a railway. O my! O my! said the stranger "what is this Daniel?" "Well" said Daniel "they are building a new Factory outside the city and to-day they are bringing in the kitchen poker". So the stranger walked off very vexed.
5190451/4895155/5190529.school_info: School: Claonar agus Carraig, Cill an Mhuilinn

5190451/4895156/5190531.title: A Funny Story
5190451/4895156/5190531.text: In Ireland long ago a big feast was supposed to be held in a certain house.  Daniel O'Connell said he would go to it and on the way two men said they would have a joke out of Daniel.  One of them came over to Daniel and said - "Tell me Daniel, is that a good five pound note", "Show it to me", said Daniel.  "Oh! it is", said Daniel putting the five pound note into his pocket.  "Oh, but I did not mean you to keep it", sad the men.  "Well", said Daniel, "it is 5 1/2 guineas for a lawyer's advice and you owe me ten and a half shillings," walking off.  When Daniel reached the place of the feast, he noticed there was writing on the gate.  He went over to it and this is what he read "No Irish pigs allowed in here" and Daniel wrote under it.  "Whoever wrote this wrote it well for the same is written on the gates of Hell".  So Daniel walked away and did not go to the feast.
5190451/4895156/5190531.school_info: School: Claonar agus Carraig, Cill an Mhuilinn

5162140/5157976/5200958.title: Daniel O'Connell
5162140/5157976/5200958.text:
One man shot another man at the Ballycoree races. The man that shot him was going to be hung. He was in jail waiting for the gallows. His wife was very upset and she went to O'Connell to do the best he could for her. O'Connell said the best way was if she could get in to see him in the court. She was let in. She put on the man's clothes and the man put her clothes on him. So when he was brought in to be hung 'twas the woman that was in it. So she was let off.



Once upon a time Daniel O'Connell called at a hotel and he would not be allowed in. So he got a tinker and he dressed him up with a good suit, gave him money and sent him to the hotel to get lodgings there for twelve months. So the tinker went and got the lodgings, and after a start he began making saucepans, and tincans and he a lot of noise. Then no lodgers would stay there and the owner of the hotel had to  leave it until the tinker left.
(continues on next page)

5162140/5157977/5200964.title: Daniel O'Connell
5162140/5157977/5200964.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



Daniel O'Connell being a lawyer was going to Court one morning. There was a man walking on the road and he said "what o'clock is it Councillor O'Connell? He said it was eleven o'clock. "I will be late for the court. I will be hanged. "O'Connell had a car and asked him to sit up beside him. "What have you done? "I have stolen a cow" said the man. "Buy a loaf a bread before you go up" said O'Connell. "When you are asked a question put a bit of bread in your mouth and let a whistle and say "leave it so" O'Connell stood up and said no man would find him guilty. So he was dismissed. When the court was over O'Connell followed him out. "Did'nt I bring you out of it well pay me now. "The man let another whistle and said "leave it so." The prisoner when bidding farewell to O'Connell gave him an advice saying "when going stealing a cow never take the cow lying by the wall. Take the one  that is lying on the hill. She is sure to be the best because the delicate one lies near the wall and the fat one lies out in the hill.
(continues on next page)

5162140/5157978/5200981.title: Daniel O'Connell
5162140/5157978/5200981.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



There were about two thousand people inside at the old Courthouse at time of O'Connell's Election. Just in front of the Courthouse one man was breaking stones When he heard all the shouting he stood up from his heap of stones and made up to see what happened. He met a man and he asked him what was wrong and the man told him it was O'Connell was elected for Clare. The man himself was O'Connell and he asked him what work he did. He told him he was a stone-breaker. "Go and break your stones for who ever is elected you will have to do that."

5177650/5176822/5202271.title: Fair Cross
5177650/5176822/5202271.text: Quite convenient to Bunratty Castle is Fair Cross, where in ancient times a great fair was held. This fair lasted a whole week, and was the custom, and is still, in many places in Ireland tolls were charged.Now it happens that at the time  one of these fairs was in progress, the great Liberator, Daniel O'Connell was passing from Limerick City to Ennis and was made to pay toll. Later when the people heard what had happened, they became so enraged that they resolved never  to allow a fair to be held there again, and consequently it was transferred to Sixmilebridge about three miles away, and there it is held ever since, but needless to say it does not last a week.

4798667/4788579/5202768.title: Story - The Tinkers' Hotel
4798667/4788579/5202768.text:
Years ago, there was a great man in Ireland named Daniel O'Connel. He was a great Irishman and he had a great hatred for the English people. In his time there was a great hotel in Dublin. English people owned it. All the rich people called to it because it was the best in Dublin at that time. Daniel O'Connel was a great scholar and a very clever man. He used always go on horseback. One day he was riding on his horse and almost every person he met on his way he asked him did he see any tinkers on the way. All the people were surprised at him to be inquiring for tinkers. At last he came to a camp of them. He stopped beside them and they got very much afraid because they thought he would arrest them for being on the road.Daniel O'Connel asked them would they do him a good turn. They said they would if they were able. Then he told two of them to be at such a house in Dublin next day. The next day they were at it. Daniel gave them as much money as would dress each of them well. They
(continues on next page)

4798667/4788599/5202792.title: Story
4798667/4788599/5202792.text:
StoryYears ago there was a very rich man living in England. He was a Tobacconist. One day there was a pig-fair in Ballinrobe in the Co Mayo A wealthy farmer in Ireland sent a lorry load of pigs to the fair. This tobacconist sent over a man to buy pigs. The man came to the lorry and looked in at the pigs. Then he said to the Irishman "how much for the first and last pigs. He marked the pigs then and he only gave 12£ for them. The Irishman asked him "what did he mean" The Englishman said I asked you how much for the first and last pigs The English man brought home the pigs and the Irishman went home  very angry. He went and told Daniel O'Connel who was the best lawyer and cleverest man in the country. Daniel was some time solving the ease and at last he asked the man to let him cut off a small little bit of the top of his right ear and that he would work a plan. The man did not want to do so but at last he let it be cut off. Then they hid it in a small box and put it at the foot of Croagh Patrick. Then the Irishman went over to England and he very angry. He asked the Tobacconist was he going to pay him for his Lorry of pigs. Well said the
(continues on next page)

5008904/4965529/5238960.title: Fr Matthew's Meeting at Kilsharvan
5008904/4965529/5238960.text:
About 90 years ago at a place known as Kilsharvan a man named Fr Matthew gave a temperance speech. While he spoke, he usually stood on the steps of house now occupied by a family of Mc Donald's. His instruction lasted for about an hour, and a great number of people were assembled there.



The aunt of the present Miss Flynn of Shallon once attended a meeting of Dan O'Connell held in Drogheda the year of which is unknown. After the meeting a linen table cloth with his image woven on it was presented to him by the Drogheda Linen Mills.

5274069/5270920/5274143.title: Daniel O' Connell
5274069/5270920/5274143.text:
About a hundred years ago, Daniel O'Connell was holding great meetings through the land at which he pleaded the cause of his country.At one of these meetings he was telling the people to buy Irish goods. Then someone in the crowd asked O'Connell if he carried out his own teachings - he should buy Irish goods himself."Yes said O'Connell the suit I wear is Irish the boots in which I stand on this platform are Irish", then
